awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Towards Secure Networked Cyber-Physical Systems: A Theoretic Framework with Bounded Rationality
awd_abstract_narration:
Securing critical networked cyber-physical systems (NCPSs) such as the power grid or transportation systems has emerged as a major national and global priority. The networked nature of such systems renders them vulnerable to a range of attacks both in cyber and physical domains as corroborated by recent threats such as the Stuxnet worm. Developing security mechanisms for such NCPSs significantly differs from traditional networked systems due to interdependence between cyber and physical subsystems (with attacks originating from either subsystem), possible cooperation between attackers or defenders, and the presence of human decision makers in the loop. The main goal of this research is to develop the necessary science and engineering tools for designing NCPS security solutions that are applicable to a broad range of application domains. 

This project will develop a multidisciplinary framework that weaves together principles from cybersecurity, control theory, networking and criminology. The framework will include novel security mechanisms for NCPSs founded on solid control-theoretic and related notions, analytical tools that allow incorporation of bounded human rationality in NCPS security, and experiments with real-world attack scenarios. A newly built cross-institutional NCPS simulator will be used to evaluate the proposed mechanisms in realistic environments. This research transcends specific cyber-physical systems domains and provides the necessary tools to building secure and trustworthy NCPSs. The broader impacts include a new infrastructure for NCPS research and education, training of students, new courses, and outreach events focused on under-represented student groups.

por.por_cntn:
Large scale cyber-physical systems (CPS) such as power grid, transportation, telecommunication, water supply, oil and gas pipelines, etc are vulnerable to malicious cyberattacks because of their networked nature of operation. This is corroborated by numerous news items that are published on a regular basis in news media across the globe.  Securing such NCPS’s is especially difficult because of interdependence of physical and cyber components of the CPS and the presence of adversaries who are dynamic and adaptive, capable to finding alternate pathways for cyber intrusion.   The intellectual merits of this research include novel scientific methodologies for identification of vulnerabilities and development of defense strategies for mitigation of cyber threats and game theoretic optimization leveraging upon synergies between cyber, physical, and human behavior realms utilizing concepts from game theory, control theory, cybersecurity, and criminology.   To this end, mathematical frameworks have been developed for identification of stability boundary of networked CPS systems in the presence of data packet loss due to cyberattacks at the sensor and actuator networks.  While the mathematical principles developed in this research apply to a broad class of CPS systems, special attention was placed on securing the power grid as it forms the core of all infrastructures.  The theoretical results were further validated using the hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experimental testbed developed in this research. While current countermeasures against cyberattacks are mostly reactive, successful future countermeasures for CPS must take into account behavioral attributes of cyber-adversaries. This research also included the often-downplayed human dimension of cyberattacks by using observations of real-time cybersecurity exercises, where CPS were subjected to cyberattacks. This rich qualitative data offered insights into human behavior, decision-making and group dynamics.  This qualitative human behavior data was then subjected to a time-series analysis to understand how adversaries adapt during any disruptions they may experience while conducting cyberattacks. The developed method helps in integration of engineering principles of CPS with human behavioral aspects of adversaries. Another method that was developed was social network analysis or graph theory modeling to understand how adversarial groups move through different stages of cyberattacks.  The foundational nature of the research led to broad impacts across multiple disciplines ranging from CPS to game theory, control theory, security, optimization, neural networks, smart grids, and HIL experimentation. The broader impacts included cross disciplinary education of students in Electrical Engineering and Criminal Justice on the basics of grid operation and adversarial behavior.  Outreach events targeted at students including under-represented groups were conducted via regular meetings of the IEEE student chapter.  Broad dissemination of the results was done using conference presentations, workshops, seminars, and online tools.
